At that time, the World-Honored One was still in the middle of the desire and form realms, sitting on a lion seat in the great jeweled pavilion, surrounded by the great assembly, expounding the Dharma.

At that time, the Jewel Woman said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
What is true speech?
What is true?

What is Dharma?
The Buddha said:

Listen attentively with utmost sincerity, and I shall explain it to you in detail.
Jewel Woman!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have three kinds of truth.
What are the three?
First, not deceiving the buddhas;

What is meant by not deceiving the buddhas, oneself, and sentient beings?
Jewel Woman!

If there are bodhisattvas who have given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, but are attached to the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, this is called deceiving the buddhas, oneself, and sentient beings.
Why is it not deceiving?
Jewel Woman!

If there are bodhisattvas who have given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, even if they experience great suffering in the hells, encounter the evil karma of wrong views and live together, are born in evil countries, give rise to evil afflictions, and their bodies are cut, stabbed, burned, and roasted, at such times they will never abandon the mind of enlightenment, will not rest, will not cease, will not fear, will not regret, and will cause the mind of enlightenment to become even broader, and will experience great suffering and distress for the sake of sentient beings.

Seeing those who suffer, their minds become even more expansive, diligently cultivating and practicing with vigor, wishing to attain enlightenment. They are not deceived by false speech, and all evil influences cannot sway them. This is called the bodhisattvas not deceiving the buddhas, themselves, and sentient beings.
Jewel Woman!
If there are bodhisattvas who do not deceive the buddhas, themselves, and sentient beings, this is called the bodhisattvas' true reality.
Jewel Woman!
Not deceiving the buddhas has four more things:
First, their minds are firm;
Second, they abide in the ultimate place;
Third, they are fully endowed with power;
Fourth, they diligently cultivate and practice with vigor.
Not deceiving oneself also has four things:
First, pure mind;
Second, sincere mind;
Third, not deceiving;
Fourth, not crooked.
Not deceiving sentient beings also has four things:
First, adornment;
Second, cultivating kindness;

fourth, embracing and taking in.
Jewel Woman!
This is called the first truth of the bodhisattva.
The truth of the bodhisattva is not abandoning sentient beings when first generating the vow.
Furthermore, Jewel Woman!
The truth of the bodhisattva is not speaking much, guarding one's speech, not speaking harshly, and speaking truthfully.

Whether in solitude, in the great assembly, or in the presence of the king, one's speech is sincere and true, not speaking falsely for the sake of wealth or possessions, not speaking falsely for the sake of sovereignty.
Even if the trichiliocosm were filled with the seven treasures, one would not speak falsely for their sake, let alone for minor matters.
Jewel Woman!
Such truth has thirty-two purities.

Twelfth, speaking words of wise conduct;
Thirteenth, speaking words of inner purity;

The truth of the bodhisattva is that whatever he says, his mouth and mind correspond.
What is meant by the correspondence of mouth and mind?
Cultivating giving leads to the attainment of enlightenment, not through stinginess and greed, this is called speaking with the correspondence of mouth and mind.
Being able to give everything is called truth.
Cultivating pure precepts leads to the attainment of enlightenment, not through breaking the precepts, this is called speaking with the correspondence of mouth and mind.

The thirty-seven factors of enlightenment and the four immeasurables are also like this.
Furthermore, Jewel Woman!
Truth is called the practice of the sages. The practice of the sages is the practice of suffering and impermanence.

Moreover, the noble practices are knowing suffering, abandoning the cause, realizing cessation, and cultivating the path. Knowing that the five aggregates have no arising characteristics is called knowing suffering.

The cause of the five aggregates is called the ultimate abandonment of the bonds of craving, not craving, not being attached, not praising, not seeking, not going, and not coming. Samatha and vipasyana have equal characteristics, without thought, without observation, without equality, without bondage, without grasping, without action, and without change. This is called cultivating the path.

Causing people not to abandon the mind of enlightenment, single-mindedly focused on enlightenment without forgetting, not apart from adornment, cultivating the methods of enlightenment, associating with wise and virtuous spiritual friends, cultivating faith, single-mindedly listening to the Dharma, aspiring to the true Dharma, diligently making progress.

The four unobstructed understandings, attaining great spiritual powers, in accordance with the Dharma giving, cultivating the four establishments of mindfulness, up to cultivating the eightfold noble path, the two dharmas of concentration and wisdom attaining the liberation of knowledge, the liberation according to the Dharma of Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas.

How do bodhisattvas expound the Vinaya?
The Buddha expounds the Vinaya in two ways.
What are the two?

Second, the Vinaya of afflictions.ğŸ”½What is meant by offense?
What is meant by Vinaya?

Having committed an offense, one quickly realizes it and does not think ill of it. Due to ignorance, one's upside-down and false thoughts deceive and trouble oneself, becoming attached to the self, sentient beings, and doubts, unable to attain liberation. One is agitated, remorseful, arrogant, negligent, and has little learning. These are called offenses.

If one can break through doubts and attain liberation, because one has attained liberation, one sees that where there is an offense is not a place, nor is it not a place. It is not the body, speech, or mind. It is neither grasped nor abandoned, and cannot be seen. It is not something done by the body, mind, or speech. If it is done by these three, it is a dharma of cessation.
If it is a dharma of cessation, who does it and who commits it?
As with offenses, all dharmas are also like this. Dharmas have no roots, no activity, and no place.
If one can destroy such doubts, this is called purity, this is called non-heat;
Acting in accordance with the teacher's instructions is called having faith, having concentration, and having the Vinaya.
What are afflictions?
What is Vinaya?
The twelve links of dependent origination, namely ignorance up to old age and death, are called afflictions.
The nature that can subdue all afflictions is called Vinaya.
Why is it so?
Emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness can subdue all phenomena.
If phenomena are empty, without inherent characteristics, and cannot be wished for, how can there be greed, anger, and delusion?
Non-action can subdue all phenomena. If all phenomena are unactionable, how can there be afflictions and bonds?
All phenomena arise from causes and conditions. If they arise from conditions, how can they be seen?
Seeing such twelve links of dependent origination, one also understands afflictions and the characteristics of afflictions.
If the wisdom of emptiness can contemplate enlightenment, then with this emptiness one makes afflictions empty.
If one can observe such equality, this is called Vinaya.
If one can expound the meaning in this way, this is called a bodhisattva who can expound Vinaya.
If one can understand the Vinaya, one will understand the Vinaya of afflictions.
What is meant by understanding the Vinaya of self?

It means contemplating non-self, contemplating the nature of self, knowing the purity of self, knowing the reality of self, knowing the discrimination of self, knowing the emptiness of self, knowing the cultivation of self, knowing the immovability of self, not speaking, not clinging, not giving rise to, and not extinguishing.
If one can understand self in this way, one will understand the Vinaya of afflictions.
If there is no self in reality, yet one has the thought of self, regarding afflictions that are non-existent, one has the thought of afflictions, which is also like this;
If self is originally non-existent, afflictions are also the same.
If one is fully endowed with vipaÅ›yanÄ, one will be able to observe and understand in this way. This is called understanding the Vinaya of self and afflictions.
Afflictions are not past, future, or present. If one does not create, does not think, and does not seek, this is called understanding the Vinaya of afflictions.

The Vinaya is also not past, present, or future. Like the mind is not form, it is neither internal nor external, nor in between. Afflictions are also like this, neither form, nor internal, external, or in between.
Why is this?
Because there is no awareness, no conflict, no purity, and no creation.
If one can know in this way that all afflictions do not arise or cease, this is called understanding the Vinaya of afflictions.

If bodhisattvas attain this kind of understanding of the Vinaya of afflictions, and also expound this kind of Dharma for sentient beings, this is called the bodhisattvas expounding the Vinaya.
When this Dharma was being spoken, ten thousand bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
